messageBody:
Jason Rogers wrote:

> On Thu, 2003-08-21 at 11:53, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > Next, I am experimenting with the following Java implementation pattern.
> > A refactoring, I think.
> >
> > * Replace private/public separation with interface/implementation
> > separation.
> >
> > In other words, rather than make methods private, which can hurt
> > testing, extract a client interface and ship it to the client. Hide
> > creating instances behind factories. In other words, do like JDBC, JMS,
> > EJB...
> >
> > I like it. Thoughts?
>
> Smalltalk-ish... (that tends to be good in my book). Does it fit the
> Java programming model? I don't know. What happens when you need to
> make a wide-sweeping interface change, say for the next major click
> level?

Well, no-one should rely on the implementation, so that's refactorable.

As for the interface, it's the same problem no matter you to do it. You
have to reach for the scourge of Java maintenance: deprecate, baby,
deprecate!
